text: having been satisfactorily identified and duly sworn by the Notary Public, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION
Good morning, Mr. Morton.  Good to see you again.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I appreciate you coming back.  Again, my name is Mark Hoover.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I just want to remind you that you are still under oath from the first couple of days of your testimony.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We shouldn't be very long today.  We kind of were going late the last couple of times and figured we'd come back, everybody fresh, and finish up.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The same rules apply as before.  Just to kind of remind you, if there's a question that I ask that you don't understand or it doesn't seem clear, just let me know and I'll rephrase it. Okay?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yup.  Yes.  Sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's okay.  And then if -- otherwise, sir, I'm going to assume that you understood our questions and that you answered them as such. Fair enough?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Again, not going to be very long today, but if you need a break for any reason, let me know and we'll take a break.  Okay?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: All right.  Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  We were back here the end of June for two days of your discovery deposition.  Since that time, sir, have you read either days of your deposition?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is there -- between Day 2, which was, I believe, the 28th of June, and today, which is almost a month later, the 26th of July, have you done any further research or work to prepare for today's deposition?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You haven't reviewed any sort of documents or spoken to any sort of coworkers or witnesses since then?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Real quick, I just want to kind of wrap up something and then we're going to talk a little bit about your medical history and treatments. I want to go back to the time when you were helping your father at Fort Devens; and in particular, the NCO Club and the officers' club.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember talking about that last time?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I believe you had mentioned that Carrier was the manufacturer of the AC compressors at those clubs.  Correct?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And these, as I understand it, were sealed units.  Correct?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In other words, like, the compressor and the motor were all in one?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were these also known as, like, hermetic compressors?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But nonetheless, they were sealed?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And any sort of maintenance on these I think would basically be kind of blow out, any sort of --
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: The condenser.  And clean the fan motor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that was just, again, to clean out the airborne dust that gathers to help efficiency, for example?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Objection.  Form.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I have no idea where the dust came from.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But it was -- again, wherever it came from, you were just blowing out that particular dust?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Right.  To -- yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And that helped with the efficiency of the units?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then there might be some sort of visual inspections as part of that work.  Right?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you happen to remember any sort of -- strike that. How did you know that these were Carrier sealed systems?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: With the nameplate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where on the system was the nameplate?  Do you recall?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Usually on the outside so it's visible, so if someone walked by and looked at it they would see the nameplate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you have a memory of how big the nameplate itself was?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Well, I can't give you exact dimensions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No.  Just your best memory, sir.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: But someone that could walk by 10 feet, they could see the name.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you happen to remember anything about any sort of color or size?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any memory of any model numbers or serial numbers?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as I understand your testimony from Day 2, if you are replacing a sealed unit, there's no real reason to do any work on it?  You just take it out as a complete unit.  Correct?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: These sealed units were not externally insulated, were they?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Externally, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then I understand your testimony from Day 2 that there was really no gasket work involved with any of these sealed units.  Correct?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Objection to form.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Going back to the times that you were working at the various mills as part -- the printing work that we talked about, do you have any memory of any abatement work being done at any of those work facilities?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: And if you don't understand what he --
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Explain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  That was going to be my next question if you didn't. Do you know what an abatement is?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any memory of anyone at any work site ever coming in and having to, for example, seal off certain areas to remove insulation or anything along those lines?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I want to include not only the places that you've worked at but also including your own business.  I know that for a while you owned your own printing.  Was there ever any abatement work done at any of your own buildings where you operated your business?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  As I mentioned, the bulk of today -- and it won't be very long -- is really to kind of go over your medical history.  Okay?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so I'm going to start, sir, do you smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever smoked?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you first start smoking?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I can just give you approximate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I certainly don't remember the day I picked up the first pack of cigarettes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: But somewhere between 12 and 14, I'm going to say.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did you last smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I can tell you that.  1989.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how old were you when you -- if we did the math?  And I can't do math very well.  That's why I went to law school.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Like 50.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Around age 50?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.  Give or take.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So from approximately the age of 12 to 14 to approximately when you were about 50 years old?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what types of cigarettes did you smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I probably started out with either Camels or Lucky Strikes.  And then -- I didn't smoke those very long.  I can't tell you how long.  And then I went to either Marlboros or Salem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how many packs a day or how many cigarettes per day, on average, would you say you smoked?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: At the highest point, a pack a day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at the lowest point?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I'm going to say 10 cigarettes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you were at the approximate pack per day, for what period of time, from the age of 12 to 50, would it be that pack per day?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Probably from 20 on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So for about 30 years?  From 20 to 50?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did your wife -- does your wife smoke? Did your wife smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Has she ever smoked?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your parents smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: One did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which one smoked?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Father.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you recall how often he would smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall if he would smoke, for example, when -- you were working with him up at Devens for a period of time.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would he smoke on the job?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And if he were driving you up to Fort Devens on the weekends -- we talked about when you were helping out there -- would he smoke in the car?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: He would.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in the wintertime, I'm assuming the windows would be up as you guys would come up here to Devens and do the work?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Objection.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: In the car.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Summertime, the windows would be down. The wintertime, the windows would be closed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  Okay.  When you were working at the -- working for the print -- doing the print work, did any of the coworkers -- your coworkers at those facilities, did any of them smoke?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were they able to smoke while they were working, or was there a designated smoking area, or was it kind of a combination?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: A combination.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you were working, would you also be smoking?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you owned your own facility -- and forgive me, I've forgotten the time frame when you started your own company.  Were you still smoking at the time you started your own company?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were there other employees when you were -- owned your own printing company that were also smoking?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said you stopped in 1989, at around the age of 50.  What caused you to stop smoking?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Automobile accident.  And I wound up in the hospital for a week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I was going to ask you a little bit about that.  I saw a reference to an auto accident.  But before we get a little bit into that, what was it about being in the hospital for a week that stopped you from smoking?  Is it just because you weren't able to, so by the time you got out you were, like, I've kicked the habit?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Exactly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Tell me a little bit about that motor vehicle accident in 1989 that caused you to be in the hospital for about a week.  Do you recall what happened?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Tell us what happened.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: A car hit me head on and I sustained knee damage.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other injuries from this head-on collision?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you wearing your seatbelt at the time?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you strike your chest at all? Any sort of chest injury?  Ribs?  Anything along those lines?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Don't know.  I don't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I didn't sustain any bruises, or anything like that, other than my right knee.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As a result of this auto accident in 1989, did you file any sort of lawsuit against the driver that hit you?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In that lawsuit against the driver, were you deposed in that case?  I know we talked about whether or not you've been deposed before.  But do you have a memory sitting down in that lawsuit and having a situation like this where a lawyer asked you questions?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember the name of your lawyer from 1989?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Jim Van Buren.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Like the president?  Van Buren, like the president?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know where he -- do you know if he's still alive?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: He's still alive.  Yup.  He is retired. Lives somewhere in the Worcester area.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did that lawsuit ever go to trial, or did the matter settle?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Went to trial.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did it go to trial in Worcester?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I'm not sure, to tell you the truth.  I don't know exactly where the trial was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the result of the trial?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: The what?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the result after the trial?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Objection. I'm really struggling trying to figure out how any of these questions are reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of any admissible evidence.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: You can -- and you can object to the form of the question.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: All right.  Well, I'm not going to let it go on much longer than this last question.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I'm not sure how to answer your question. Meaning --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you don't know, Mr. Morton, just say you don't know.  We don't want you to guess or speculate.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I'm not guessing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I received a settlement.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Don't discuss anything about the amount of any funds you may have received, Mr. Morton.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I'm not asking --
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: And the passenger of the other car received a settlement.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: From the driver of the other car?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I have no idea where.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Gotcha.  Okay.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I know . . .
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And again, I'm not trying to, you know, confuse you or anything like that.  I was just curious. Did the jury find for you?  Did the jury find for the other driver?  If you remember.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Objection. He just answered that question to the best of his ability.  Let's move on.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: To the best of your ability, you remember that you received something?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I received something.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let him ask the question, Mr. Morton.  Just let him ask a question.  Don't answer unless there is a pending question.  Okay, sir?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Okay.  So my understanding is that it went to trial.  And as a result of the trial, at the end of it, you received something.  Right?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the passenger of the other car received something.  Right?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Other than that lawsuit, do you have any memory -- and this one -- of any other lawsuits?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Getting back to smoking -- your smoking history, do you ever remember seeing any sort of warnings on packs of cigarettes?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Time frame?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, either you do remember seeing warnings or you don't.  And then we'll get into a time frame.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: When I first started, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At some point in time, then, you do remember seeing warnings on cigarettes?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know approximately when that was that you first noticed warnings on cigarettes?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Sometime in the '80s.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as a result of seeing those warnings, did you change the manner or the amount of smoking that you did?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did any doctor ever tell you that you should quit smoking?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Back in the 1980s, did you have a primary care physician or a PCP?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever go for regular yearly checkups or anything?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Today do you have a primary care physician?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who is your primary care physician today?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Dr. Cerel.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where is Dr. Cerel located?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: In Ayer, Mass.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is this a private practice, or is Dr. Cerel part of a group?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Dr. Cerel, is there a first name?  Is it male?  Female?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: What's that?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The first name of Dr. Cerel.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Adam.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did you first start to go see Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Approximately 2005.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And prior to 2005, did you have a primary care physician?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you were growing up, I'm assuming your parents would take you to the doctor for checkups?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then at some point did you just stop going to see a doctor?  Like on yearly checkups, for example.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Well, in my days you didn't need a primary.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: We had a family doctor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And growing up, who was your family doctor?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Dr. Cominos.  And obviously, he's not around any more.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so Dr. Cominos was the family doctor that you and your siblings and your parents might go to for whatever you needed.  Right?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At some point did you switch or take on a new doctor that kind of you'd go to if you needed to see one?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who would that be?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I can't think of his name.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's okay.  Again, just your best memory is what we're looking for here.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And this unknown doctor, the one we can't remember, how long would you say that was your family doctor slash primary care provider?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: He tried to get me in there once a year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was he successful?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Pretty much so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And would you say -- do you have a memory of approximately how long you went to see this doctor?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you see him for?  Over what period of time?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: 10, 15 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Until approximately when would you say you last saw this guy?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: So between 2000 and 2005, did you see somebody before going to see Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Actually, change that.  2000 to close 2004.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And then following this doctor, you started to see Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was Dr. Cerel just, you know, for example, yearly checkups and the like?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What took you to see Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Heart failure.  Cardiologist.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was the last time you saw Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Three months ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is this all part of the checkup and monitoring of your heart?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Other than Dr. Cerel -- strike that. Did Dr. Cerel, in addition to kind of working with you on the heart issues, also serve for just general overall medical?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And how frequently do you see Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Three to six months.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's, again, to kind of monitor your heart?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: And pacemaker.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  Other than seeing Dr. Cerel as a cardiologist, do you have any other specialists that you see or that you treat with?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Well, obviously because of the cancer. Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And I want to kind of leave that just separately and we'll get -- obviously, ask you about that. Aside from that, are there any other specialists that you see, for example, for heart, the pacemaker, or anything along those lines, other than Dr. Cerel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think I asked early on, probably in the beginning when we started this whole thing, if you were on any sort of medications that would affect your memory or your ability to testify.  And you said that there weren't.  But are you currently taking any medications today?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been referred to a pulmonologist at any time?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Before we delve into your current condition, I want to do, obviously, a little bit about your medical history itself.  And we touched on the heart failure that you sustained in working with Dr. Cerel.  So let me ask a little bit about that. When were you first diagnosed with any sort of heart either disease or heart issues?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: That was '05.  That's where I made the switch.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So did someone diagnose you with heart failure?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: My initial doctor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  The one we can't remember?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when was that diagnosis made?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Obviously '05.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was happening to you that led to that diagnosis?  In other words, what took you to that doctor?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Shortness of breath, obviously fatigue, and didn't feel well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so as a result of some symptoms, you went to see this particular doctor?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: My doctor referred me to Dr. Cerel.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Gotcha.  And as a result of this referral, what did Dr. Cerel do?  What did he discover?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: He discovered that heart failure.  And my AF was, like, 18.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as a result of what he discovered, what did -- what sort of procedures did you undergo?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Basically, I went down to Boston, to Beth Israel.  He referred me.  They inserted a pacemaker and defibrillator.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was this in 2005?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have a sense of when in 2005? Winter, spring, summer?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know who performed the procedure at Beth Israel?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long were you at Beth Israel while they put in the pacemaker and the defibrillator?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: A week, rough.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then you were discharged from Beth Israel.  Correct?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever have to go back to Beth Israel for followups or checkups on that?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: I did because of a lead situation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did that happen?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Two years ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah, roughly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So between '05 and 2016 -- so for 11 years -- did you ever have to go back?
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was Dr. Cerel the one who was monitoring, then, the pacemaker and the defibrillator?

text: We're talking about just the Bell & Gossett right now.  Did you take any of those Bell & Gossett pumps apart; and if so, why did you do so and what were you doing?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Yes.  Replaced the flange gasket.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you doing any other work on those pumps?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And were you only at -- were you just at this diner one time for installation, or were you going back to do maintenance work on the pumps?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Multiple different places.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you mean "multiple different places"?  We're talking -- you testified to working with B&G pumps at a diner in Ayer, Mass. Are you telling me that you worked with those pumps at other locations or at multiple locations in the diner?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Besides in the diner.  Is that accurate?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Besides the diner.  Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what were -- what were the other locations where you would've worked with Bell & Gossett pumps?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Objection.  Form. If you don't understand what --

text: I don't understand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm going to move on to the Goulds pumps.  You had also indicated that you installed Goulds pumps at the Park Street Diner in Ayer. Do you recall the function of those Goulds pumps at the Park Street Diner?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: No, I don't.

text: No.

text: Not at the diner.

text: Okay.  Now, you had also indicated that you worked with -- you had Goulds pumps in the basement of your house and that you rebuilt that pump sometime between 1980 and 1985. Do you recall the function of that pump? I know you said generally it was a water pump, but what exactly was the function, if you recall?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Supply water to the house.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So it was a well pump?
speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: It was a well pump, shallow well pump.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And I think you insinuated in answering questions with regards to the Park Street Diner that you had worked with Goulds pumps somewhere other than the Park Street Diner and in your home.  Is that correct?

text: Yes.

speaker: MR. GEORGE

text: Yeah.  Roughly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you very much, sir. That's all the questions I have for you.

text: I have a couple of questions.  Let me switch sides just for purposes of the camera. EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Mr. Morton, earlier this morning you told us about how you started smoking at the age of either 12 or 14 and you quit in 1989.  Do you recall that testimony?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You also told us that the first time you ever noticed any warnings on any cigarette packs was at some point in the 1980s.  Do you recall that testimony?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  At that time, when you first noticed the warnings on the cigarette packs, were you addicted to smoking cigarettes?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I object to the form.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry.  What was your answer?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After you read the warnings for the first time in the 1980s, did you become concerned about the health consequences of smoking?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you do with those concerns that you had?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I first tried quitting several times.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  How many times specifically, if you remember, did you try quitting before you were finally successful in quitting in 1989?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Roughly twice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why were you unsuccessful those two times before you were finally able to overcome it in 1989?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Because cigarettes are very addictive.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you also told us earlier this morning that in 1989 you were finally able to quit smoking for good.  Do you recall that testimony?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was the primary driving force behind your desire to quit smoking in 1989?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: I was in the hospital for a week and not able to smoke.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Were you concerned about the health consequences at that point in time?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is that one of the driving forces behind why you wanted to quit for good in 1989?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I object to the form.
speaker: MR. HOOVER

text: You also told us that you currently still drive.  Do you recall that testimony, Mr. Morton?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: That what?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That you still drive.  You still drive a vehicle.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Oh, yes, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you wear your seatbelt when you drive?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why do you wear your seatbelt?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: For protection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you're driving, Mr. Morton, and you're approaching an intersection and the light turns yellow, what do you do?
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: You slow down and try to stop.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just generally speaking --
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Folks on the phone, can you please mute your phones.  We're hearing a lot of conversation in the background.
speaker: MR. BECERRA

text: Mr. Morton, just a couple more questions and then we'll be done. Just generally speaking, Mr. Morton, when you're using any product, whether it's a home cleaning product or any other type of product, and there's a warning on those products, do you read those warnings?
